text: today on x cast after a night of
fighting Libyan rebels appear to have
control of zoo aya Christian Dior fires
its chief designer John Galliano over
anti-semitic slurs and Governor Scott
Walker of Wisconsin presents his budget
Tuesday as the collective bargaining
standoff continues this is David
Kirkpatrick reporting from Tripoli for
the New York Times the news today mostly
centers on a town about 30 miles from
here called sawaya we visited hawaii a
couple days ago and found it to be
firmly in the hands of the rebels who
are trying to force colonel muammar
qaddafi from power a surprisingly large
portion of the libyan army had defected
to join them they had tanks
anti-aircraft guns coalition a coughs
and they were they were celebrating we
wondered how long this could last
because the next day Gaddafi's most
formidable battalion the Hemis militia
was lined up on the row so we were we
were bracing for some kind of clash and
apparently that happened last night at
around seven-thirty it appears that the
rebels have held the town the last we
heard last night this morning is that
the government forces lost 10 men while
the rebels lost none the other
experience we had here today is we were
led on an official tour of hospital we
were introduced to some wounded people
sitting in their hospital beds who for
whatever reason and i think it was
coercion told us that they had in fact
been shot by anti-government protesters
none of which I find very credible nor
did I find it very credible when a
doctor appeared forced to tell us that
everything in the hospital was normal
and there had been no influx of
casualties in recent days the hospital
tour was part of the officially
sponsored visit that has brought me and
a number of other journalists here this
week if their intention was to sort of
control what we see they haven't done a
very good job because we very often been
able to get into direct contact with the
rebels to visit rebel-held cities
rebel-held neighborhoods to meet with
people who are openly scornful of
Colonel Qaddafi as Paris Fashion Week
begins one of the biggest designers is
mired in controversy the name John
Galliano has become synonymous with
Christian Dior over the last decade
and now that designer is in trouble
after having been accused of making
anti-semitic slurs in a Paris bar dior
has been forced first to suspend John
Galliano and then to fire him but it
wasn't until the smoking gun appeared a
video put up by the Sun newspaper
tabloid in London of another incident
where John Galliano was caught saying
really horrific and anti-semitic things
like you would be dead they're often
moments within the industry when people
know that designers are behaving very
badly drugs and alcohol are very much
part of the profession and a probably
some people weren't surprised to hear
that John Galliano was found in the
Marais which is a trendy quarter of
Paris completely drunk shouting abuses
cynical buckled up those are words you
can't say even more when you are a
personality or in public but he got
fired so fast I was very surprised
nobody's quite sure what this will mean
for the house of deal it is after all an
enormous brand but fly this show must go
on that is the view of banner on oh the
president of LVMH and for good reason
because so much is carried on a show and
the images that it creates and wisconsin
Governor Scott Walker presents his
budget to the state legislature I'm
Monica daviet from the New York Times
and we're at the State Capitol in
Wisconsin so what's happening here right
now is that there are a lot of
protesters now waiting outside the
Capitol building for the second day in a
row they're not being let in there are
some protesters a really small number
inside still but it's nothing like it
was when this all began two weeks ago
one of the concerns is that Governor
Walker is supposed to give his budget
address at four o'clock today the
administration has set a bunch of rules
to keep people out today to keep a
limited number of people going in who
are supposed to participate in hearings
and official business but most regular
people can't go in and a lot of these
people are pretty unhappy about that
so that was that was Glenn Grothman who
just walked in a conservative Republican
it was red Kessler not surprisingly a
Democrat in the assembly the people on
the outside here the protesters say look
you need to come halfway we've agreed to
some of these pension and healthcare
cuts we're okay with that just drop
collective bargaining from the
conversation this is not about money it
never has been almost two weeks ago the
union leaders for the state workers had
agreed in full to the concessions
demanded by the governor even though it
means that workers making thirty forty
thousand dollars a year will lose
thousands of dollars from their pockets
and that's really going to hurt our
economy they just said don't take away
our collective bargaining rights that's
what we can't give up what Governor
Walker said is no I can't drop
collective bargaining and if you all
don't agree to it I'm going to have to
begin cutting hundreds perhaps thousands
of workers to make up for this deficit
join us again tomorrow four times cast
